CHARGED EXOTIC CHARMONIUM STATES

Abstract

In this short review we present and discuss all the experimental information about the charged exotic charmonium states, which have been observed over the last five years. We try to understand their properties such as masses and decay widths with QCD sum rules. We describe this method, show the results and compare them with the experimental data and with other theoretical approaches.

keywords:
exotic states; non-perturbative methods.

1 Introduction

Since its first observation in 2003 by the Belle Collaboration [1], the Xâ€‹(3872)ğ‘‹3872X(3872) has attracted the interest of all the hadronic community. It is the most well studied state among the new charmonium states and has been confirmed by five collaborations: CDF [2], D0 [3], BaBar [4], LHCb [5] and CMS [6]. There is little doubt in the community that the Xâ€‹(3872)ğ‘‹3872X(3872) structure is more complex than just a câ€‹cÂ¯ğ‘Â¯ğ‘c\bar{c} state. Besides the Xâ€‹(3872)ğ‘‹3872X(3872) the other recently observed charmonium states that clearly have a more complex structure than câ€‹cÂ¯ğ‘Â¯ğ‘c\bar{c} are the charged states. Up to now there are some experimental evidences for seven charged states, which are shown in Table 1.

The first charged charmonium state, the Z+â€‹(4430)superscriptğ‘4430Z^{+}(4430), was observed by the Belle Collaboration in 2008, produced in B+â†’Kâ€‹(Ïˆâ€²â€‹Ï€+)â†’superscriptğµğ¾superscriptğœ“â€²superscriptğœ‹B^{+}\to K(\psi^{\prime}\pi^{+}) [7]. However the Babar Collaboration [8] searched for the Zâˆ’â€‹(4430)superscriptğ‘4430Z^{-}(4430) signature in four decay modes and concluded that there is no significant evidence for a signal peak in any of these processes. Very recently the Belle Collaboration has confirmed the Z+â€‹(4430)superscriptğ‘4430Z^{+}(4430) observation and has determined the preferred assignment of the quantum numbers to be JP=1+1superscriptğ½ğ‘ƒsuperscript11J^{P}=1^{+1} [9]. Curiously, there are no reports of a Z+superscriptğ‘Z^{+} signal in the J/Ïˆâ€‹Ï€+ğ½ğœ“superscriptğœ‹J/\psi\pi^{+} decay channel.

The Z+â€‹(4430)superscriptğ‘4430Z^{+}(4430) observation motivated further studies of other BÂ¯0superscriptÂ¯ğµ0\bar{B}^{0} decays. The Belle Collaboration has reported the observation of two resonance-like structures, called Z1+â€‹(4050)superscriptsubscriptğ‘14050Z_{1}^{+}(4050) and Z2+â€‹(4250)superscriptsubscriptğ‘24250Z_{2}^{+}(4250), in the exclusive process BÂ¯0â†’Kâˆ’â€‹Ï€+â€‹Ï‡câ€‹1â†’superscriptÂ¯ğµ0superscriptğ¾superscriptğœ‹subscriptğœ’ğ‘1\bar{B}^{0}\to K^{-}\pi^{+}\chi_{c1}, in the Ï€+â€‹Ï‡câ€‹1superscriptğœ‹subscriptğœ’ğ‘1\pi^{+}\chi_{c1} mass distribution [10]. Once again the BaBar colaboration did not confirm these observations [11].

After these non confirmations, it was with great excitement that the hadron community heard about the observation of the Zc+â€‹(3900)superscriptsubscriptğ‘ğ‘3900Z_{c}^{+}(3900). The Zc+â€‹(3900)superscriptsubscriptğ‘ğ‘3900Z_{c}^{+}(3900) was first observed by the BESIII collaboration in the (Ï€Â±â€‹J/Ïˆ)superscriptğœ‹plus-or-minusğ½ğœ“(\pi^{\pm}J/\psi) mass spectrum of the Yâ€‹(4260)â†’J/Ïˆâ€‹Ï€+â€‹Ï€âˆ’â†’ğ‘Œ4260ğ½ğœ“superscriptğœ‹superscriptğœ‹Y(4260)\to J/\psi\pi^{+}\pi^{-} decay channel [12]. This structure, was also observed at the same time by the Belle collaboration [13] and was confirmed by the authors of Ref. Â [\refciteXiao:2013iha] using CLEO-c data.

Soon after the Zc+â€‹(3900)superscriptsubscriptğ‘ğ‘3900Z_{c}^{+}(3900) observation, the BESIII related the observation of other three charges states: Zc+â€‹(4025)superscriptsubscriptğ‘ğ‘4025Z_{c}^{+}(4025) [15], Zc+â€‹(4020)superscriptsubscriptğ‘ğ‘4020Z_{c}^{+}(4020) [16] and Zc+â€‹(3885)superscriptsubscriptğ‘ğ‘3885Z_{c}^{+}(3885) [17]. Up to now it is not clear if the states Zc+â€‹(3900)superscriptsubscriptğ‘ğ‘3900Z_{c}^{+}(3900)-Zc+â€‹(3885)superscriptsubscriptğ‘ğ‘3885Z_{c}^{+}(3885) and the states Zc+â€‹(4025)superscriptsubscriptğ‘ğ‘4025Z_{c}^{+}(4025)-Zc+â€‹(4020)superscriptsubscriptğ‘ğ‘4020Z_{c}^{+}(4020) are the same states seen in different decay channels, or if they are independent states.

All these charged states can not be câ€‹cÂ¯ğ‘Â¯ğ‘c\bar{c} states and they are natural candidates for molecular or tetraquark states. These exotic states are allowed by the strong interactions, both at the fundamental level and at the effective level, and their absence in the experimentally measured spectrum has always been a mystery. The theoretical tools to address these questions are lattice QCD, chiral perturbation theory, QCD sum rules (QCDSR), effective lagrangian approaches and quark models. For more details we refer the reader to the more comprehensive Ref.Â [\refcitenora] and to the more recent and also more specific Ref.Â [\refcitereliu] review articles.

In this rapidly evolving field, periodic accounts of the status of theory and experiment are needed. There are already several reviews of the recent charmonium spectroscopy. The present one is focused on the charged states and on the QCDSR approach to them. In the next sections we discuss some of these new charmonium states using the QCDSR approach.

2 QCD Sum Rules

The method of the QCDSR is a powerful tool to evaluate the masses and decay widths of hadrons based on first principles. It was first introduced by Shifman, Vainshtein and Zakharov [20] to the study of mesons, and was latter extended to baryons by Ioffe [21] and Chung et al. [22, 23]. Since then the QCDSR technique has been applied to study numerous hadronic properties with various flavor content and has been discussed in many reviews [24, 25, 26, 27, 28] emphasizing different aspects of the method. The method is based on identities between two- or three-point correlation functions, which connect hadronic observables with QCD fundamental parameters, such as quark masses, the strong coupling constant, and quantities which characterize the QCD vacuum, i.e., the condensates. The correlation function is of a dual nature: it represents a quark-antiquark fluctuation for short distances (or large momentum) and can be treated in perturbative QCD, while at large distances (or small momentum) it can be related to hadronic observables. The sum rule calculations are based on the assumption that in some range of momentum both descriptions are equivalent. One, thus, proceeds by calculating the correlation function for both cases and by eventually equating them to obtain information on the properties of the hadrons.

In principle, QCDSR allow first-principle calculations. In practice, however, in order to extract results, it is necessary to make expansions, truncations, and other approximations that may reduce the power of the formalism and introduce large errors. However, if one can find ways to control these errors, the method can provide important informations about the structure of the hadrons.

2.1 Hadron masses

The QCD sum rule calculations of the mass of a hadronic state are based on the correlator of two hadronic currents. A generic two-point correlation function is given by

In the QCDSR approach the correlation function is evaluated in two different ways: at the quark level in terms of quark and gluon fields and at the hadronic level introducing hadron characteristics such as the mass and the coupling of the hadronic state to the current jâ€‹(x)ğ‘—ğ‘¥j(x).

The hadronic side, or phenomenological side of the sum rule is evaluated by writing a dispersion relation to the correlator in Eq.Â (1):

Using Eq.Â (9) in Eq.Â (4) we get

Î pâ€‹hâ€‹eâ€‹nâ€‹(q2)=âˆ’Î»2q2âˆ’m2âˆ’âˆ«s0âˆğ‘‘sâ€‹ÏOâ€‹Pâ€‹Eâ€‹(s)q2âˆ’s+iâ€‹Ïµ+â‹¯,superscriptÎ ğ‘â„ğ‘’ğ‘›superscriptğ‘2superscriptğœ†2superscriptğ‘2superscriptğ‘š2superscriptsubscriptsubscriptğ‘ 0differential-dğ‘ superscriptğœŒğ‘‚ğ‘ƒğ¸ğ‘ superscriptğ‘2ğ‘ ğ‘–italic-Ïµâ‹¯\Pi^{phen}(q^{2})=-{\lambda^{2}\over q^{2}-m^{2}}\,-\,\int_{s_{0}}^{\infty}ds\,{\rho^{OPE}(s)\over q^{2}-s+i\epsilon}\,+\,\cdots\,, (10)

To improve the matching of the two descriptions of the correlator one applies the Borel transformation. The Borel transformation removes the subtraction terms in the dispersion relation, and exponentially suppresses the contribution from excited resonances and continuum states in the phenomenological side. In the OPE side the Borel transformation suppresses the contribution from higher dimension condensates by a factorial term.

After performing a Borel transform on both sides of the sum rule, and transferring the continuum contribution to the OPE side, the sum rule can be written as

Î»2â€‹eâˆ’m2/M2=âˆ«smâ€‹iâ€‹ns0ğ‘‘sâ€‹eâˆ’s/M2â€‹ÏOâ€‹Pâ€‹Eâ€‹(s).superscriptğœ†2superscriptğ‘’superscriptğ‘š2superscriptğ‘€2superscriptsubscriptsubscriptğ‘ ğ‘šğ‘–ğ‘›subscriptğ‘ 0differential-dğ‘ superscriptğ‘’ğ‘ superscriptğ‘€2superscriptğœŒğ‘‚ğ‘ƒğ¸ğ‘ \lambda^{2}e^{-m^{2}/M^{2}}=\int_{s_{min}}^{s_{0}}ds~{}e^{-s/M^{2}}~{}\rho^{OPE}(s)\;. (11)

A good sum rule is obtained in the case that one can find a range of M2superscriptğ‘€2M^{2}, called Borel window, in which the two sides have a good overlap and information on the lowest resonance can be extracted. To determine the allowed Borel window, one analyses the OPE convergence and the pole contribution: the minimum value of the Borel mass is fixed by considering the convergence of the OPE, and the maximum value of the Borel mass is determined by imposing the condition that the pole contribution must be bigger than the continuum contribution.

The mass of the hadronic state, mğ‘šm, can be obtained by taking the derivative of Eq.Â (11) with respect to 1/M21superscriptğ‘€21/M^{2}, and dividing the result by Eq.Â (11):

m2=âˆ«smâ€‹iâ€‹ns0ğ‘‘sâ€‹eâˆ’s/M2â€‹sâ€‹ÏOâ€‹Pâ€‹Eâ€‹(s)âˆ«smâ€‹iâ€‹ns0ğ‘‘sâ€‹eâˆ’s/M2â€‹ÏOâ€‹Pâ€‹Eâ€‹(s).superscriptğ‘š2superscriptsubscriptsubscriptğ‘ ğ‘šğ‘–ğ‘›subscriptğ‘ 0differential-dğ‘ superscriptğ‘’ğ‘ superscriptğ‘€2ğ‘ superscriptğœŒğ‘‚ğ‘ƒğ¸ğ‘ superscriptsubscriptsubscriptğ‘ ğ‘šğ‘–ğ‘›subscriptğ‘ 0differential-dğ‘ superscriptğ‘’ğ‘ superscriptğ‘€2superscriptğœŒğ‘‚ğ‘ƒğ¸ğ‘ m^{2}={\int_{s_{min}}^{s_{0}}ds~{}e^{-s/M^{2}}~{}s~{}\rho^{OPE}(s)\over\int_{s_{min}}^{s_{0}}ds~{}e^{-s/M^{2}}~{}\rho^{OPE}(s)}\;. (12)

Using the formalism described above we can compute the masses of the new states. A compilation of results of the states discussed here is shown in Table 2. These numbers will be discussed in detail in the next sections.

2.2 Hadron decay widths

The QCD sum rule calculations for the coupling constant in a hadronic vertex are based on the correlator of three hadronic currents. A generic three-point correlation function associated with a vertex of three mesons M1subscriptğ‘€1M_{1}, M2subscriptğ‘€2M_{2} and M3subscriptğ‘€3M_{3} is given by

Î“â€‹(p,pâ€²,q)=âˆ«d4â€‹xâ€‹d4â€‹yâ€‹eiâ€‹pâ€²â‹…xâ€‹eâˆ’iâ€‹qâ‹…yâ€‹âŸ¨0|Tâ€‹{j3â€‹(x)â€‹j2â€ â€‹(y)â€‹j1â€ â€‹(0)}|0âŸ©Î“ğ‘superscriptğ‘â€²ğ‘superscriptğ‘‘4ğ‘¥superscriptğ‘‘4ğ‘¦superscriptğ‘’â‹…ğ‘–superscriptğ‘â€²ğ‘¥superscriptğ‘’â‹…ğ‘–ğ‘ğ‘¦quantum-operator-product0ğ‘‡subscriptğ‘—3ğ‘¥superscriptsubscriptğ‘—2â€ ğ‘¦superscriptsubscriptğ‘—1â€ 00\Gamma(p,p^{\prime},q)=\int d^{4}x\,d^{4}y\;\;e^{ip^{\prime}\cdot x}\,e^{-iq\cdot y}\langle 0|T\{j_{3}(x)j_{2}^{\dagger}(y)j_{1}^{\dagger}(0)\}|0\rangle\, (13)

where q=pâ€²âˆ’pğ‘superscriptğ‘â€²ğ‘q=p^{\prime}-p and the current jisubscriptğ‘—ğ‘–j_{i} represents states with the quantum numbers of the meson iğ‘–i. As in the case of the two-point correlation function, the function in Eq.Â (13) is evaluated in two ways. In the OPE side we consider that the currents are composed by quarks and we use the Wilsonâ€™s OPE to evaluate the correlation function. In the phenomenological side, we insert, in Eq.(13), intermediate states for the mesons M1subscriptğ‘€1M_{1}, M2subscriptğ‘€2M_{2} and M3subscriptğ‘€3M_{3}. We then write the correlation function in terms of the coupling of these mesons with the corresponding currents, and in terms of the form factor, gM1â€‹M2â€‹M3â€‹(q2)subscriptğ‘”subscriptğ‘€1subscriptğ‘€2subscriptğ‘€3superscriptğ‘2g_{M_{1}M_{2}M_{3}}(q^{2}), in the hadronic vertex, which is defined by the generalization of the on-mass-shell matrix element, âŸ¨M3â€‹M2|M1âŸ©inner-productsubscriptğ‘€3subscriptğ‘€2subscriptğ‘€1\langle M_{3}M_{2}|M_{1}\rangle, for an off-shell M2subscriptğ‘€2M_{2} meson:

âŸ¨M3â€‹(pâ€²)â€‹M2â€‹(q)|M1â€‹(p)âŸ©=gM1â€‹M2â€‹M3â€‹(q2)â€‹fM1,pâ€‹fM2,pâ€²â€‹fM3,q,inner-productsubscriptğ‘€3superscriptğ‘â€²subscriptğ‘€2ğ‘subscriptğ‘€1ğ‘subscriptğ‘”subscriptğ‘€1subscriptğ‘€2subscriptğ‘€3superscriptğ‘2subscriptğ‘“subscriptğ‘€1ğ‘subscriptğ‘“subscriptğ‘€2superscriptğ‘â€²subscriptğ‘“subscriptğ‘€3ğ‘\langle M_{3}(p^{\prime})M_{2}(q)|M_{1}(p)\rangle=g_{M_{1}M_{2}M_{3}}(q^{2})f_{M_{1},p}f_{M_{2},p^{\prime}}f_{M_{3},q}, (14)

which can be extracted from the effective Lagrangian that describes the coupling between these three mesons. In Eq.Â (14) the functions fMi,ksubscriptğ‘“subscriptğ‘€ğ‘–ğ‘˜f_{M_{i},k} are obained from the Lagrangian and are related with the quantum numbers of the meson Misubscriptğ‘€ğ‘–M_{i}. After evaluating both sides separately, we equate one description with the other and we can extract the form factor from the sum rule.

The coupling constant is defined as the value of the form factor at the meson pole: Q2=âˆ’m22superscriptğ‘„2superscriptsubscriptğ‘š22Q^{2}=-m_{2}^{2}, where m2subscriptğ‘š2m_{2} is the mass of the meson M2subscriptğ‘€2M_{2} that was off-shell. Very often, in order to determine the coupling constant we have to extrapolate the QCDSR results to a Q2superscriptğ‘„2Q^{2} region where the sum rules are no longer valid (since the QCDSR results are valid in the deep Euclidian region). To do that, in general, we parametrize the QCDSR results through a analytical form, like a monopole or an exponential function. For more details we refer the reader to Ref.Â [\refciteBracco:2011pg].

3 Xâ€‹(3872)ğ‘‹3872X(3872)

The Xâ€‹(3872)ğ‘‹3872X(3872) was first observed by Belle collaboration in 2003 in the decay B+â†’Xâ€‹(3872)â€‹K+â†’J/Ïˆâ€‹Ï€+â€‹Ï€âˆ’â€‹K+â†’superscriptğµğ‘‹3872superscriptğ¾â†’ğ½ğœ“superscriptğœ‹superscriptğœ‹superscriptğ¾B^{+}\!\rightarrow\!X(3872)K^{+}\rightarrow\!J/\psi\pi^{+}\pi^{-}K^{+} [1], and has been confirmed by other five collaborations [2, 3, 4, 5, 6]. The current world average mass is mX=(3871.68Â±0.17)subscriptğ‘šğ‘‹plus-or-minus3871.680.17m_{X}=(3871.68\pm 0.17) MeV and its total width is less than 1.21.21.2 MeV [32]. The LHCb collaboration determined JPâ€‹C=1++superscriptğ½ğ‘ƒğ¶superscript1absentJ^{PC}=1^{++} quantum numbers with more than 8Ïƒğœ\sigma significance [33].

3.1 Mass

Calculations using constituent quark models give masses for possible charmonium states, with JPâ€‹C=1++superscriptğ½ğ‘ƒğ¶superscript1absentJ^{PC}=1^{++} quantum numbers, which are much bigger than the observed Xâ€‹(3872)ğ‘‹3872X(3872) mass: 2â€‹P13â€‹(3990)2superscriptsubscriptğ‘ƒ1339902~{}^{3}P_{1}(3990) and 3â€‹P13â€‹(4290)3superscriptsubscriptğ‘ƒ1342903~{}^{3}P_{1}(4290) [34]. These results, together with the coincidence between the Xğ‘‹X mass and the Dâˆ—0â€‹D0superscriptğ·absent0superscriptğ·0D^{*0}D^{0} threshold: Mâ€‹(Dâˆ—0â€‹D0)=(3871.81Â±0.36)â€‹MeVğ‘€superscriptğ·absent0superscriptğ·0plus-or-minus3871.810.36MeVM(D^{*0}D^{0})=(3871.81\pm 0.36)\nobreak\,\mbox{MeV} [35], inspired the proposal that the Xâ€‹(3872)ğ‘‹3872X(3872) could be a molecular (Dâˆ—0â€‹DÂ¯0+DÂ¯âˆ—0â€‹D0)superscriptğ·absent0superscriptÂ¯ğ·0superscriptÂ¯ğ·absent0superscriptğ·0(D^{*0}\bar{D}^{0}+\bar{D}^{*0}D^{0}) bound state with small binding energy [36, 37, 38, 39, 40].

Other interesting possible interpretation of the Xâ€‹(3872)ğ‘‹3872X(3872), first proposed by Maiani et al. [41], is that it could be a tetraquark state resulting from the binding of a diquark and an antidiquark.

The fisrt QCDSR calculation of the mass of the Xâ€‹(3872)ğ‘‹3872X(3872) considered as a JPâ€‹C=1++superscriptğ½ğ‘ƒğ¶superscript1absentJ^{PC}=1^{++} tetraquark state was done in Ref.Â [\refcitex3872]. Following this calculation, a JPâ€‹C=1++superscriptğ½ğ‘ƒğ¶superscript1absentJ^{PC}=1^{++}, Dâˆ—â€‹DÂ¯superscriptğ·Â¯ğ·D^{*}\bar{D} molecular current was considered in Ref.Â [\refcitekorea]. The corresponding interpolating currents used in these calculations are:

In the OPE side, the calculations were done at leading order in Î±ssubscriptğ›¼ğ‘ \alpha_{s} and contributions of condensates up to dimension eight were included. In both cases it was possible to find a Borel window where the pole contribution is bigger than the continuum contribution and with a reasonable OPE convergence.

The mass obtained in Ref.Â [\refcitex3872], considering the allowed Borel window and the uncertaities in the parameters, was mX=(3.92Â±0.13)subscriptğ‘šğ‘‹plus-or-minus3.920.13m_{X}=(3.92\pm 0.13) GeV whereas the result for the mass obtained in Ref.Â [\refcitekorea] was mX=(3.87Â±0.07)subscriptğ‘šğ‘‹plus-or-minus3.870.07m_{X}=(3.87\pm 0.07) GeV, as shown in Table 2.

We see that, in both cases, a good agreement with the experimental mass was obtained. Up to now there are many QCDSR calculations[28] of the the mass of the Xâ€‹(3872)ğ‘‹3872X(3872) considering different currents and in all cases good agreement with the experimental mass is found. Even with a mixed charmonium-molecular current the value obtained for the mass does not change significantly [44]. These calculations only confirm the result presented in Ref.Â [\refciteNarison:2010pd] that shows that the calculation of the mass of a given state, in the QCDSR approach, is very insensitive to the choice of the current. However, this may not be the case for the decay width[45].

3.2 Decay width

The first QCDSR calculation of the width of the Xâ€‹(3872)ğ‘‹3872X(3872) was done in Ref.Â [\refcitewidth]. In particular, in Ref.Â [\refcitewidth] the Xâ€‹(3872)ğ‘‹3872X(3872) was considered as a tetraquark state described by the current in Eq.Â (15) and a very large decay width was obtained: Î“â€‹(Xâ†’J/Ïˆâ€‹Ïâ†’J/Ïˆâ€‹Ï€+â€‹Ï€âˆ’)=(50Â±15)â€‹MeVÎ“â†’ğ‘‹ğ½ğœ“ğœŒâ†’ğ½ğœ“superscriptğœ‹superscriptğœ‹plus-or-minus5015MeV\Gamma(X\to J/\psi\rho\to J/\psi\pi^{+}\pi^{-})=(50\pm 15)~{}\nobreak\,\mbox{MeV}. A similar width was obtained in Ref.Â [\refcitex24] with a molecular current such as the one in Eq.Â (16). Indeed, large partial decay widths are expected when the coupling constant is obtained from QCDSR, in the case of multiquark states, when the initial state contains the same number of valence quarks as the number of valence quarks in the final state. An example is the case of the light scalars Ïƒğœ\sigma and Îºğœ…\kappa studied in Ref.Â [\refcitesca], which widths are of the order of 400 MeV. In the case of the Xâ†’J/Ïˆâ€‹Ïâ†’ğ‘‹ğ½ğœ“ğœŒX\to J/\psi\rho decay, the generic decay diagram in terms of quarks has two â€œpetalsâ€, one associated with the J/Ïˆğ½ğœ“J/\psi and the other with the ÏğœŒ\rho.

Among the possible diagrams, there are two distinct subsets. Diagrams with no gluon exchange between the petals, as the one shown in Fig.Â 1(a), and therefore, no color exchange between the two final mesons in the decay. If there is no color exchange, the final state containing two color singlets was already present in the initial state. In this case the tetraquark had a component similar to a J/Ïˆâˆ’Ïğ½ğœ“ğœŒJ/\psi-\rho molecule. The other subset of diagrams is the one where there is a gluon exchange between the petals, as the one shown in Fig.Â 1(b). This type of diagram represents the case where the Xğ‘‹X is a genuine four-quark state with a complicated color structure. These diagrams are called color-conected (CC). Considering only the CC diagrams in the calculation, the decay width obtained in Ref.Â [\refcitewidth] was:

Î“Câ€‹Câ€‹(Xâ†’J/Ïˆâ€‹Ïâ†’Jâ€‹Ïˆâ€‹Ï€+â€‹Ï€âˆ’)=(0.7Â±0.2)â€‹MeV,subscriptÎ“ğ¶ğ¶â†’ğ‘‹ğ½ğœ“ğœŒâ†’ğ½ğœ“superscriptğœ‹superscriptğœ‹plus-or-minus0.70.2MeV\Gamma_{CC}(X\to J/\psi~{}\rho\to J\psi\pi^{+}\pi^{-})=(0.7\pm 0.2)~{}\nobreak\,\mbox{MeV}, (17)

in a very good agreement with the experimental upper limit.

This procedure may appear somewhat unjustified. However, if the initial state has a non-trivial color structure only CC diagrams should contribute to the calculation. Unfortunately, although the initial tetraquark current has a non-trivial color structure, it can be rewritten as a sum of molecular type currents with trivial color configuration through a Fierz transformation. This is the reason why the diagrams without gluon exchange between the two â€œpetalsâ€ survive in the QCDSR calculation. Therefore, the approach of considering only CC diagrams can be considered as a form of simulating a real tetraquark state with non-trivial color structure.

Other possible approach to reduce the large widht is to consider the Xâ€‹(3872)ğ‘‹3872X(3872) as a mixture between a câ€‹cÂ¯ğ‘Â¯ğ‘c\bar{c} current and a molecular current, as done in Ref.Â [\refcitex24]:

JÎ¼â€‹(x)=sinâ¡(Î±)â€‹jÎ¼mâ€‹oâ€‹lâ€‹(x)+cosâ¡(Î±)â€‹jÎ¼2â€‹(x),subscriptğ½ğœ‡ğ‘¥ğ›¼subscriptsuperscriptğ‘—ğ‘šğ‘œğ‘™ğœ‡ğ‘¥ğ›¼subscriptsuperscriptğ‘—2ğœ‡ğ‘¥J_{\mu}(x)=\sin(\alpha)j^{mol}_{\mu}(x)+\cos(\alpha)j^{2}_{\mu}(x), (18)

with jÎ¼mâ€‹oâ€‹lâ€‹(x)subscriptsuperscriptğ‘—ğ‘šğ‘œğ‘™ğœ‡ğ‘¥j^{mol}_{\mu}(x) given in Eq.Â (16) and

jÎ¼2â€‹(x)=16â€‹2â€‹âŸ¨qÂ¯â€‹qâŸ©â€‹[cÂ¯aâ€‹(x)â€‹Î³Î¼â€‹Î³5â€‹caâ€‹(x)].subscriptsuperscriptğ‘—2ğœ‡ğ‘¥162delimited-âŸ¨âŸ©Â¯ğ‘ğ‘delimited-[]subscriptÂ¯ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘¥subscriptğ›¾ğœ‡subscriptğ›¾5subscriptğ‘ğ‘ğ‘¥j^{2}_{\mu}(x)={1\over 6\sqrt{2}}\langle\bar{q}q\rangle[\bar{c}_{a}(x)\gamma_{\mu}\gamma_{5}c_{a}(x)]. (19)

The necessity of mixing a câ€‹cÂ¯ğ‘Â¯ğ‘c\bar{c} component with the D0â€‹DÂ¯âˆ—0superscriptğ·0superscriptÂ¯ğ·absent0D^{0}\bar{D}^{*0} molecule was already pointed out in some works [48, 49, 50, 51]. In particular, in Ref.Â [\refcitegrinstein], a simulation of the production of a bound D0â€‹DÂ¯âˆ—0superscriptğ·0superscriptÂ¯ğ·absent0D^{0}\bar{D}^{*0} state with binding energy as small as 0.25 MeV, obtained a cross section of about two orders of magnitude smaller than the prompt production cross section of the Xâ€‹(3872)ğ‘‹3872X(3872) observed by the CDF Collaboration. The authors of Ref.Â [\refcitegrinstein] concluded that Sğ‘†S-wave resonant scattering is unlikely to allow the formation of a loosely bound D0â€‹DÂ¯âˆ—0superscriptğ·0superscriptÂ¯ğ·absent0D^{0}\bar{D}^{*0} molecule in high energy hadron collision.

As discussed above, there is no problem in reproducing the experimental mass of the Xâ€‹(3872)ğ‘‹3872X(3872), using the current in Eq.Â (18), for a wide range of the mixture angle Î±ğ›¼\alpha. However, the value of the Xâ€‹J/Ïˆâ€‹Ïğ‘‹ğ½ğœ“ğœŒXJ/\psi\rho coupling constant and, therefore, the value of the Xâ†’J/Ïˆâ€‹(nâ€‹Ï€)â†’ğ‘‹ğ½ğœ“ğ‘›ğœ‹X\to J/\psi~{}(n\pi) decay width, is strongly dependent on this angle. It was shown in Ref.Â [\refcitex24] that for a mixing angle Î±=90Â±40ğ›¼plus-or-minussuperscript90superscript40\alpha=9^{0}\pm 4^{0}, it is possible to describe the experimental mass of the Xâ€‹(3872)ğ‘‹3872X(3872) with a decay width Î“â€‹(Xâ†’J/Ïˆâ€‹(nâ€‹Ï€))=(9.3Â±6.9)â€‹MeVÎ“â†’ğ‘‹ğ½ğœ“ğ‘›ğœ‹plus-or-minus9.36.9MeV\Gamma(X\to J/\psi~{}(n\pi))=(9.3\pm 6.9)~{}\nobreak\,\mbox{MeV}, which is compatible with the experimental upper limit. Therefore, in a QCDSR calculation, the Xâ€‹(3872)ğ‘‹3872X(3872) can be well described basically by a câ€‹cÂ¯ğ‘Â¯ğ‘c\bar{c} current with a small, but fundamental, admixture of molecular (Dâ€‹DÂ¯âˆ—ğ·superscriptÂ¯ğ·D\bar{D}^{*}) or tetraquark ([câ€‹q]â€‹[cÂ¯â€‹qÂ¯]delimited-[]ğ‘ğ‘delimited-[]Â¯ğ‘Â¯ğ‘[cq][\bar{c}\bar{q}]) currents.

4 Z+â€‹(4430)superscriptğ‘4430Z^{+}(4430)

Since the Z+â€‹(4430)superscriptğ‘4430Z^{+}(4430) mass is close to the Dâˆ—â€‹D1superscriptğ·subscriptğ·1D^{*}D_{1} threshold, it was suggested that it could be an S-wave threshold effect or a Dâˆ—â€‹D1superscriptğ·subscriptğ·1D^{*}D_{1} molecular state. There are QCDSR calculations for the Z+â€‹(4430)superscriptğ‘4430Z^{+}(4430) assuming that the state could have JP=0âˆ’superscriptğ½ğ‘ƒsuperscript0J^{P}=0^{-} or JP=1âˆ’superscriptğ½ğ‘ƒsuperscript1J^{P}=1^{-} quantum numbers [53, 54]. These numbers are displayed in Table 2.

From these results the preliminary conclusion, at the time, was that the assignment JP=1âˆ’superscriptğ½ğ‘ƒsuperscript1J^{P}=1^{-} was disfavored and that the configuration JP=0âˆ’superscriptğ½ğ‘ƒsuperscript0J^{P}=0^{-}, in both molecular and tetraquark states, would lead to a mass which is in agreement with the data. However, a recent reanalysis of the Belle data revealed that the favored quantum numbers are JP=1+superscriptğ½ğ‘ƒsuperscript1J^{P}=1^{+} [9]. It is important to mention that soon after the Z+â€‹(4430)superscriptğ‘4430Z^{+}(4430) was first observed, Maiani et al. have suggested that the Z+â€‹(4430)superscriptğ‘4430Z^{+}(4430) could be the first radial excitation of a charged partner of the Xâ€‹(3872)ğ‘‹3872X(3872), and therefore, would have JP=1+superscriptğ½ğ‘ƒsuperscript1J^{P}=1^{+} quantum numbers [55]. The existence of a charged partner of the Xâ€‹(3872)ğ‘‹3872X(3872) was first proposed in Ref.Â [\refcitemaiani].

Clearly, in view of the recent experimental reanalysis, if the Z+â€‹(4430)superscriptğ‘4430Z^{+}(4430) really exist, it could be a Ïˆâ€²â€‹Ï€+superscriptğœ“â€²superscriptğœ‹\psi^{\prime}\pi^{+} resonance or a tetraquark excitation, which invalidates a QCDSR calculation.

Since the masses of the Z1+â€‹(4050)superscriptsubscriptğ‘14050Z_{1}^{+}(4050) and Z2+â€‹(4250)superscriptsubscriptğ‘24250Z_{2}^{+}(4250) are close to the Dâˆ—â€‹Dâˆ—Â¯â€‹(4020)superscriptğ·Â¯superscriptğ·4020D^{*}\bar{D^{*}}(4020) and D1â€‹DÂ¯â€‹(4085)subscriptğ·1Â¯ğ·4085D_{1}\bar{D}(4085) thresholds, it is natural to interpret these states as molecular states or threshold effects. However calculations using meson exchange models do not agree with each other. In Ref.Â [\refciteding2] the interpretation of Z2+â€‹(4250)superscriptsubscriptğ‘24250Z_{2}^{+}(4250) as a D1â€‹DÂ¯subscriptğ·1Â¯ğ·D_{1}\bar{D} or D0â€‹Dâˆ—Â¯subscriptğ·0Â¯superscriptğ·D_{0}\bar{D^{*}} molecule was disfavored.

Soon after the observation of these states, QCDSR were used[59] to study the Dâˆ—â€‹DÂ¯âˆ—superscriptğ·superscriptÂ¯ğ·D^{*}\bar{D}^{*} and D1â€‹DÂ¯subscriptğ·1Â¯ğ·D_{1}\bar{D} molecular states with IGâ€‹JP=1âˆ’â€‹0+superscriptğ¼ğºsuperscriptğ½ğ‘ƒsuperscript1superscript0I^{G}J^{P}=1^{-}0^{+} and 1âˆ’â€‹1âˆ’superscript1superscript11^{-}1^{-} respectively. The currents used in both cases were of the type of Eq.Â (16). As shown in Table 2, for the Dâˆ—â€‹Dâˆ—Â¯superscriptğ·Â¯superscriptğ·D^{*}\bar{D^{*}} system the obtained mass was mDâˆ—â€‹Dâˆ—=(4.15Â±0.12)subscriptğ‘šsuperscriptğ·superscriptğ·plus-or-minus4.150.12m_{D^{*}D^{*}}=(4.15\pm 0.12) GeV. Since the central value of the mass is around 130 MeV above the Dâˆ—â€‹Dâˆ—â€‹(4020)superscriptğ·superscriptğ·4020D^{*}D^{*}(4020) threshold, we can conclude that there are repulsive interactions between the two Dâˆ—superscriptğ·D^{*} mesons. Therefore, it is not clear whether this structure is a resonance or not. For the D1â€‹DÂ¯subscriptğ·1Â¯ğ·D_{1}\bar{D} system the obtained mass was mD1â€‹D=(4.19Â±0.22)subscriptğ‘šsubscriptğ·1ğ·plus-or-minus4.190.22m_{D_{1}D}=(4.19\pm 0.22) GeV. Here, in contrast to the previous case, the central value is around 100 MeV below the D1â€‹Dâ€‹(4285)subscriptğ·1ğ·4285D_{1}D(4285) threshold, and, considering the errors, consistent with the mass of the Z2+â€‹(4250)superscriptsubscriptğ‘24250Z_{2}^{+}(4250) resonance structure. Therefore, in this case, there seems to be an atractive interaction between the mesons D1subscriptğ·1D_{1} and Dğ·D and the molecular interpretation of this state seems more justified.

QCD sum rules estimate always contain some uncertainties. In the study of the masses of the charged Zğ‘Z states, part of the theoretical uncertainty comes from the width of the state. In most cases, the widht is neglected. In the present case, when the width is included in the phenomenological side of the sum rule, the mass of the corresponding state increases[60]. It becomes then possible to obtain a mass mD1â€‹D=4.25â€‹GeVsubscriptğ‘šsubscriptğ·1ğ·4.25GeVm_{D_{1}D}=4.25~{}\nobreak\,\mbox{GeV} with a width 40â‰¤Î“â‰¤60â€‹MeV40Î“60MeV40\leq\Gamma\leq 60~{}\nobreak\,\mbox{MeV}. Following the same trend, the mass of the Dâˆ—â€‹DÂ¯âˆ—superscriptğ·superscriptÂ¯ğ·D^{*}\bar{D}^{*} molecule will be far from the Z1+â€‹(4050)superscriptsubscriptğ‘14050Z_{1}^{+}(4050) mass. In view of these facts, the authors of Ref.Â [\refciteleeniel] concluded that it is possible to describe the Z2+â€‹(4250)superscriptsubscriptğ‘24250Z_{2}^{+}(4250) as a D1â€‹DÂ¯subscriptğ·1Â¯ğ·D_{1}\bar{D} molecular state with IGâ€‹JP=1âˆ’â€‹1âˆ’superscriptğ¼ğºsuperscriptğ½ğ‘ƒsuperscript1superscript1I^{G}J^{P}=1^{-}1^{-} quantum numbers. They also concluded that the Dâˆ—â€‹DÂ¯âˆ—superscriptğ·superscriptÂ¯ğ·D^{*}\bar{D}^{*} state is probably a virtual state that is not related with the Z1+â€‹(4050)superscriptsubscriptğ‘14050Z_{1}^{+}(4050) resonance-like structure. Since the Dâˆ—â€‹Dâˆ—superscriptğ·superscriptğ·D^{*}D^{*} threshold (4020)4020(4020) is so close to the Z1+â€‹(4050)superscriptsubscriptğ‘14050Z_{1}^{+}(4050) mass and the Î·câ€²â€²â€‹(31â€‹S0)subscriptsuperscriptğœ‚â€²â€²ğ‘superscript31subscriptğ‘†0\eta^{\prime\prime}_{c}(3^{1}S_{0}) mass is predicted to be around 4050 MeV, the Z1+â€‹(4050)superscriptsubscriptğ‘14050Z_{1}^{+}(4050) is probably only a threshold effect.

6 Zc+â€‹(3900)subscriptsuperscriptğ‘ğ‘3900Z^{+}_{c}(3900)

After the non-confirmed observations of Z+â€‹(4430)superscriptğ‘4430Z^{+}(4430), Z1+â€‹(4050)subscriptsuperscriptğ‘14050Z^{+}_{1}(4050) and Z2+â€‹(4250)subscriptsuperscriptğ‘24250Z^{+}_{2}(4250), only seen by Belle, the BESIII and Belle collaborations reported the observation of a charged charmonium-like structure in the Mâ€‹(Ï€Â±â€‹J/Ïˆ)ğ‘€superscriptğœ‹plus-or-minusğ½ğœ“M(\pi^{\pm}J/\psi) mass spectrum of the Yâ€‹(4260)â†’J/Ïˆâ€‹Ï€+â€‹Ï€âˆ’â†’ğ‘Œ4260ğ½ğœ“superscriptğœ‹superscriptğœ‹Y(4260)\to J/\psi\pi^{+}\pi^{-} decay channel [12, 13]. The existence of this structure, called Zcâ€‹(3900)subscriptğ‘ğ‘3900Z_{c}(3900), was promptly confirmed by the the authors of Ref.Â [\refciteXiao:2013iha] using CLEO-c data.

In most of the theoretical calculations it is relatively easy to reproduce the masses of the states. In the case of the Zcâ€‹(3900)subscriptğ‘ğ‘3900Z_{c}(3900), assuming Sâ€‹Uâ€‹(2)ğ‘†ğ‘ˆ2SU(2) symmetry, the mass obtained in QCDSR for the Zcsubscriptğ‘ğ‘Z_{c} is exactly the same one obtained for the Xâ€‹(3872)ğ‘‹3872X(3872). As discussed in Sec. 3.2, it is, however, much more difficult to reproduce their measured decay widths. The Zcâ€‹(3900)subscriptğ‘ğ‘3900Z_{c}(3900) decay width represents a challenge to theorists. While its mass is very close to the Xâ€‹(3872)ğ‘‹3872X(3872) mass, which may be considered its isosinglet partner, it has a much larger decay width. Indeed, while the Zcâ€‹(3900)subscriptğ‘ğ‘3900Z_{c}(3900) decay width is in the range 40âˆ’50405040-50 MeV, the Xâ€‹(3872)ğ‘‹3872X(3872) width is smaller than 1.21.21.2 MeV.

This difference can be attributed to the fact that the Xâ€‹(3872)ğ‘‹3872X(3872) may contain a significant |câ€‹cÂ¯âŸ©ketğ‘Â¯ğ‘|c\bar{c}\rangle component[44], which is absent in the Zcâ€‹(3990)subscriptğ‘ğ‘3990Z_{c}(3990). As pointed out in Ref.Â [\refcitezhao], this would also explain why the Zcsubscriptğ‘ğ‘Z_{c} has not been observed in BğµB decays.

According to the experimental observations, the Zcâ€‹(3900)subscriptğ‘ğ‘3900Z_{c}(3900) decays into J/Ïˆâ€‹Ï€+ğ½ğœ“superscriptğœ‹J/\psi\,\pi^{+} with a relatively large decay width. This is unexpected for a Dâˆ—âˆ’DÂ¯superscriptğ·Â¯ğ·D^{*}-\bar{D} molecular state, in which the distance between the Dâˆ—superscriptğ·D^{*} and the DÂ¯Â¯ğ·\bar{D} is large. This decay must involve the exchange of a charmed meson, which is a short range process and hence unlikely to occur in large systems. In Ref.Â [\refcitenamit] it was shown that, in order to reproduce the measured width, the effective radius must be âŸ¨reâ€‹fâ€‹fâŸ©â‰ƒ0.4similar-to-or-equalsdelimited-âŸ¨âŸ©subscriptğ‘Ÿğ‘’ğ‘“ğ‘“0.4\langle r_{eff}\rangle\simeq 0.4 fm. This size scale is small and pushes the molecular picture to its limit of validity. In another work[63], the new state was treated as a charged Dâˆ—âˆ’DÂ¯superscriptğ·Â¯ğ·D^{*}-\bar{D} molecule and the authors explored its electromagnetic structure, arriving at the conclusion that its charge radius is of the order of âŸ¨r2âŸ©â‰ƒ0.11similar-to-or-equalsdelimited-âŸ¨âŸ©superscriptğ‘Ÿ20.11\langle r^{2}\rangle\simeq 0.11 fm2. Taking this radius as a measure of the spatial size of the state, we conclude that it is more compact than a J/Ïˆğ½ğœ“J/\psi, for which âŸ¨r2âŸ©â‰ƒ0.16similar-to-or-equalsdelimited-âŸ¨âŸ©superscriptğ‘Ÿ20.16\langle r^{2}\rangle\simeq 0.16 fm2. In Ref.Â [\refciteDias:2013xfa] the combined results of Refs.Â [\refcitenamit] and [\refcitehammer] were taken as an indication that the Zcsubscriptğ‘ğ‘Z_{c} is a compact object, which may be better understood as a quark cluster, such as a tetraquark. Moreover, the Zcâ€‹(3900)subscriptğ‘ğ‘3900Z_{c}(3900) was interpreted as the isospin 1 partner of the Xâ€‹(3278)ğ‘‹3278X(3278), as the charged state predicted in Ref.Â [\refcitemaiani]. 7 Zc+â€‹(4025)subscriptsuperscriptğ‘ğ‘4025Z^{+}_{c}(4025), Zc+â€‹(4020)subscriptsuperscriptğ‘ğ‘4020Z^{+}_{c}(4020) and Zc+â€‹(3885)subscriptsuperscriptğ‘ğ‘3885Z^{+}_{c}(3885) : are they real ?

Very recently the BESIII Collaboration reported the observation of other three charges states: Zc+â€‹(4025)superscriptsubscriptğ‘ğ‘4025Z_{c}^{+}(4025) [15], Zc+â€‹(4020)superscriptsubscriptğ‘ğ‘4020Z_{c}^{+}(4020) [16] and Zc+â€‹(3885)superscriptsubscriptğ‘ğ‘3885Z_{c}^{+}(3885) [17].

In the BESIII set-up a reaction e+â€‹eâˆ’â†’(Dâˆ—â€‹Dâˆ—Â¯)Â±â€‹Ï€âˆ“â†’superscriptğ‘’superscriptğ‘’âˆ’superscriptsuperscriptğ·Â¯superscriptğ·plus-or-minussuperscriptğœ‹minus-or-pluse^{+}e^{âˆ’}\rightarrow(D^{*}\bar{D^{*}})^{\pm}\pi^{\mp} was performed at s=4.26ğ‘ 4.26\sqrt{s}=4.26 GeV and a peak was seen in the (Dâˆ—â€‹Dâˆ—Â¯)Â±superscriptsuperscriptğ·Â¯superscriptğ·plus-or-minus(D^{*}\bar{D^{*}})^{\pm} invariant mass distribution just about 101010 MeV above the threshold. The peak was identified as a new particle, the Zc+â€‹(4025)superscriptsubscriptğ‘ğ‘4025Z_{c}^{+}(4025) [15]. The authors assume in the paper that the (Dâˆ—â€‹Dâˆ—Â¯)Â±superscriptsuperscriptğ·Â¯superscriptğ·plus-or-minus(D^{*}\bar{D^{*}})^{\pm} pair is created in a S-wave and then the Zc+â€‹(4025)superscriptsubscriptğ‘ğ‘4025Z_{c}^{+}(4025) must have JP=1+superscriptğ½ğ‘ƒsuperscript1J^{P}=1^{+} to match, together with the pion, the quantum numbers JP=1âˆ’superscriptğ½ğ‘ƒsuperscript1J^{P}=1^{-} of the virtual photon from the e+â€‹eâˆ’superscriptğ‘’superscriptğ‘’e^{+}e^{-} pair. However, they also state that the experiment does not exclude other spin-parity assignments. Since the (Dâˆ—â€‹Dâˆ—Â¯)Â±superscriptsuperscriptğ·Â¯superscriptğ·plus-or-minus(D^{*}\bar{D^{*}})^{\pm} has charge, the isospin must be I = 1.

In parallel with the experimental works many theoretical papers were devoted to understand these new states. In Ref.Â [\refcitehidalgo], Heavy Quark Spin Symmetry (HQSS) was used to make predictions for states containing one Dğ·D or Dâˆ—superscriptğ·D^{*} and one DÂ¯Â¯ğ·\bar{D} or Dâˆ—Â¯Â¯superscriptğ·\bar{D^{*}}. Assuming the Xâ€‹(3872)ğ‘‹3872X(3872) to be Dâ€‹Dâˆ—Â¯ğ·Â¯superscriptğ·D\bar{D^{*}} molecule, the authors found a series of new hadronic molecules, including the Zc+â€‹(3900)superscriptsubscriptğ‘ğ‘3900Z_{c}^{+}(3900) and the Zc+â€‹(4025)superscriptsubscriptğ‘ğ‘4025Z_{c}^{+}(4025). They would correspond to bound states (with uncertainties of about 505050 MeV in the binding) of Dâ€‹Dâˆ—Â¯ğ·Â¯superscriptğ·D\bar{D^{*}} and Dâˆ—â€‹Dâˆ—Â¯superscriptğ·Â¯superscriptğ·D^{*}\bar{D^{*}} respectively, with quantum numbers Iâ€‹(JP)=1â€‹(1+)ğ¼superscriptğ½ğ‘ƒ1superscript1I(J^{P})=1(1^{+}). Remarkably, even with uncertainties, these states always appear in the bound region. In Refs.Â [\refcitechen,cui], using QCD sum rules and assuming a structure of Dâˆ—â€‹Dâˆ—Â¯superscriptğ·Â¯superscriptğ·D^{*}\bar{D^{*}}, the authors obtained a possible Iâ€‹(JP)=1â€‹(1+)ğ¼superscriptğ½ğ‘ƒ1superscript1I(J^{P})=1(1^{+}) state compatible with the Zc+â€‹(4025)superscriptsubscriptğ‘ğ‘4025Z_{c}^{+}(4025) albeit with around 250250250 MeV uncertainty in the energy. Recently [69], a study of the Dâˆ—â€‹Dâˆ—Â¯superscriptğ·Â¯superscriptğ·D^{*}\bar{D^{*}} system has also been done within QCD sum rules, projecting the correlation function on spin-parity 0+superscript00^{+}, 1+superscript11^{+} and 2+superscript22^{+}. In the three cases a state with mass 3950Â±100plus-or-minus39501003950\pm 100 MeV was found. The central value of the mass of these states is more in line with the results of Refs.Â [\refciteraquel,oset], although with the error bar, they could as well be related to a resonance. In Ref.Â [\refcitesunzhu] the new Zcsubscriptğ‘ğ‘Z_{c} states were investigated from a different perspective and, using pion exchange, a Dâˆ—â€‹Dâˆ—Â¯superscriptğ·Â¯superscriptğ·D^{*}\bar{D^{*}} state with Iâ€‹(JP)=1â€‹(1+)ğ¼superscriptğ½ğ‘ƒ1superscript1I(J^{P})=1(1^{+}) compatible with the Zcâ€‹(4025)subscriptğ‘ğ‘4025Z_{c}(4025) was obtained. One should note that the input used in this latter work is quite different from the one in Ref.Â [\refcitehidalgo] since in HQSS the pion exchange is subdominant. Finally, in Ref.Â [\refciteqtang], using a tetraquark structure and QCDSR, a state with Iâ€‹(JP)=1â€‹(2+)ğ¼superscriptğ½ğ‘ƒ1superscript2I(J^{P})=1(2^{+}) compatible with Zcâ€‹(4025)subscriptğ‘ğ‘4025Z_{c}(4025) was obtained, once again with a large error in the energy of 190190190 MeV. In a different analysis, in Ref.Â [\refcitematsuki] a pion and the Dâˆ—â€‹Dâˆ—Â¯superscriptğ·Â¯superscriptğ·D^{*}\bar{D^{*}} state are produced from the Xâ€‹(4260)ğ‘‹4260X(4260) and the Dâˆ—â€‹Dâˆ—Â¯superscriptğ·Â¯superscriptğ·D^{*}\bar{D^{*}} state is left to interact, while the pion remains a spectator (initial single-pion emission mechanism). Although it is not mentioned whether the Dâˆ—â€‹Dâˆ—Â¯superscriptğ·Â¯superscriptğ·D^{*}\bar{D^{*}} interaction produces a resonance with certain quantum numbers, the authors show that the mechanism can produce some enhancement in the Dâˆ—â€‹Dâˆ—Â¯superscriptğ·Â¯superscriptğ·D^{*}\bar{D^{*}} invariant mass distribution just above threshold.

Bumps close to the threshold of a pair of particles should be treated with caution. Sometimes they are identified as new particles, but they can also be a reflection of a resonance below threshold. In a similar reaction, e+â€‹eâˆ’â†’J/Ïˆâ€‹(Dâ€‹DÂ¯)â†’superscriptğ‘’superscriptğ‘’ğ½ğœ“ğ·Â¯ğ·e^{+}e^{-}\rightarrow J/\psi(D\bar{D}), the Belle Collaboration reported [75] a bump close to the threshold in the (Dâ€‹DÂ¯)ğ·Â¯ğ·(D\bar{D}) invariant mass distribution, which was tentatively interpreted as a new resonance. However, in Ref.Â [\refcitegamm08] it was shown that the bump was better interpreted in terms of a (Dâ€‹DÂ¯)ğ·Â¯ğ·(D\bar{D}) molecular state, below the (Dâ€‹DÂ¯)ğ·Â¯ğ·(D\bar{D}) threshold (the so called Xâ€‹(3700)ğ‘‹3700X(3700)). Similarly, in Ref.Â [\refcitetokhenno13] the Ï•â€‹Ï‰italic-Ï•ğœ”\phi\,\omega threshold peak measured [78] in the J/Ïˆâ†’Î³â€‹Ï•â€‹Ï‰â†’ğ½ğœ“ğ›¾italic-Ï•ğœ”J/\psi\rightarrow\gamma\phi\omega reaction was better interpreted as a signal of the f0â€‹(1710)subscriptğ‘“01710f_{0}(1710) resonance, below the Ï•â€‹Ï‰italic-Ï•ğœ”\phi\,\omega threshold, which couples strongly to Ï•â€‹Ï‰italic-Ï•ğœ”\phi\,\omega. Further examples of this phenomenon may be found in Ref.Â [\refcitetokhenno14]. In that work the theory of Dâˆ—â€‹Dâˆ—Â¯superscriptğ·Â¯superscriptğ·D^{*}\bar{D^{*}} interactions is reviewed and it is pointed out that a (Dâˆ—â€‹Dâˆ—Â¯)superscriptğ·Â¯superscriptğ·(D^{*}\bar{D^{*}}) state with a mass above the threshold is very difficult to support. In particular, in Ref.Â [\refciteoset] it was found that there is only one bound state of (Dâˆ—â€‹Dâˆ—Â¯)superscriptğ·Â¯superscriptğ·(D^{*}\bar{D^{*}}) in IG=1âˆ’superscriptğ¼ğºsuperscript1I^{G}=1^{-}, with quantum numbers JPâ€‹C=2++superscriptğ½ğ‘ƒğ¶superscript2absentJ^{PC}=2^{++} with a mass around 399039903990 MeV and a width of about 100100100 MeV. Both mass and width are compatible with the reanalysis of data carried out in Ref.Â [\refcitetokhenno14]. Therefore, we can conclude that such JP=2+superscriptğ½ğ‘ƒsuperscript2J^{P}=2^{+} Dâˆ—â€‹DÂ¯âˆ—superscriptğ·superscriptÂ¯ğ·D^{*}\bar{D}^{*} bound state provides a natural explanation for the state observed in [15].

An argument against the existence of a new resonance above the threshold is the fact that if the state were a JP=1+superscriptğ½ğ‘ƒsuperscript1J^{P}=1^{+} produced in S-wave, as assumed in the experimental work, it would easily decay into J/Ïˆâ€‹Ï€ğ½ğœ“ğœ‹J/\psi\pi exchanging a Dğ·D meson in the t-channel. This is also the decay channel of the Zcâ€‹(3900)subscriptğ‘ğ‘3900Z_{c}(3900), which would then have the same quantum numbers as the state claimed in Ref.Â [\refciteAblikim:2013emm]. However, while a peak is clearly seen in the J/Ïˆâ€‹Ï€ğ½ğœ“ğœ‹J/\psi\pi invariant mass distribution in the case of the Zcâ€‹(3900)subscriptğ‘ğ‘3900Z_{c}(3900), no trace of a peak is seen around 402540254025 MeV in spite of using the same reaction and the same e+â€‹eâˆ’superscriptğ‘’superscriptğ‘’e^{+}e^{-} energy.

Less than a month after the observation of the Zc+â€‹(4025)superscriptsubscriptğ‘ğ‘4025Z_{c}^{+}(4025), the BESIII Collaboration reported the observation of the Zc+â€‹(4020)superscriptsubscriptğ‘ğ‘4020Z_{c}^{+}(4020), a structure observed in the hcâ€‹Ï€Â±subscriptâ„ğ‘superscriptğœ‹plus-or-minush_{c}\pi^{\pm} mass spectrum [16] . The difference between the parameters of this structure and the Zc+â€‹(4025)superscriptsubscriptğ‘ğ‘4025Z_{c}^{+}(4025), observed in the Dâˆ—â€‹Dâˆ—Â¯superscriptğ·Â¯superscriptğ·D^{*}\bar{D^{*}} final state, is within 1.5â€‹Ïƒ1.5ğœ1.5\,\sigma and it is not clear whether they are the same state or not. The authors do not find a significant signal for Zc+â€‹(3900)â†’hcâ€‹Ï€Â±â†’superscriptsubscriptğ‘ğ‘3900subscriptâ„ğ‘superscriptğœ‹plus-or-minusZ_{c}^{+}(3900)\rightarrow h_{c}\pi^{\pm}.

Since the Zc+â€‹(4025)superscriptsubscriptğ‘ğ‘4025Z_{c}^{+}(4025) and the Zc+â€‹(4020)superscriptsubscriptğ‘ğ‘4020Z_{c}^{+}(4020) have almost the same mass and their quantum numbers were not yet accurately determined, we might think that they are, in fact, the same particle. Looking only at the most natural quantum numbers of the final states, the S-wave Dâˆ—â€‹Dâˆ—Â¯superscriptğ·Â¯superscriptğ·D^{*}\bar{D^{*}} states have the quantum numbers JP=0+superscriptğ½ğ‘ƒsuperscript0J^{P}=0^{+}, 1+superscript11^{+} and 2+superscript22^{+}, while the S-wave hcâ€‹Ï€Â±subscriptâ„ğ‘superscriptğœ‹plus-or-minush_{c}\pi^{\pm} states have the quantum numbers JP=1âˆ’superscriptğ½ğ‘ƒsuperscript1J^{P}=1^{-}. Therefore the Zc+â€‹(4025)superscriptsubscriptğ‘ğ‘4025Z_{c}^{+}(4025) and Zc+â€‹(4020)superscriptsubscriptğ‘ğ‘4020Z_{c}^{+}(4020) would be different particles. However, it is also possible to have a P-wave hcâ€‹Ï€Â±subscriptâ„ğ‘superscriptğœ‹plus-or-minush_{c}\pi^{\pm} system with quantum numbers JP=0+superscriptğ½ğ‘ƒsuperscript0J^{P}=0^{+} 1+superscript11^{+} and 2+superscript22^{+}. In this case the Zc+â€‹(4025)superscriptsubscriptğ‘ğ‘4025Z_{c}^{+}(4025) and the Zc+â€‹(4020)superscriptsubscriptğ‘ğ‘4020Z_{c}^{+}(4020) could be the same particle.

In the analysis presented in Ref.Â [\refcitegang1], the author concluded that QCDSR do not support the picture of Zc+â€‹(4025)superscriptsubscriptğ‘ğ‘4025Z_{c}^{+}(4025) and Zc+â€‹(4020)superscriptsubscriptğ‘ğ‘4020Z_{c}^{+}(4020) as diquark-antidiquark vector tetraquark states with JP=1âˆ’superscriptğ½ğ‘ƒsuperscript1J^{P}=1^{-}. A short time later, in Ref.Â [\refcitegang2] the author concluded that, for these two states (treated as a single state), the QCDSR analysis supports the assignements JP=1+superscriptğ½ğ‘ƒsuperscript1J^{P}=1^{+} and JP=2+superscriptğ½ğ‘ƒsuperscript2J^{P}=2^{+} in a diquark-antidiquark configuration.

Shortly after the observation of the Zc+â€‹(4020)superscriptsubscriptğ‘ğ‘4020Z_{c}^{+}(4020) the same collaboration reported the measurement of the Zc+â€‹(3885)superscriptsubscriptğ‘ğ‘3885Z_{c}^{+}(3885), a charged structure observed in the (Dâ€‹Dâˆ—Â¯)Â±limit-fromğ·Â¯superscriptğ·plus-or-minus(D\bar{D^{*}})\pm invariant mass distribution [17]. The mass and width of this structure are 2â€‹Ïƒ2ğœ2\sigma and 1â€‹Ïƒ1ğœ1\sigma, respectively, below those of the Zc+â€‹(3900)superscriptsubscriptğ‘ğ‘3900Z_{c}^{+}(3900). The angular distribution of the Ï€â€‹Zcâ€‹(3885)ğœ‹subscriptğ‘ğ‘3885\pi Z_{c}(3885) system favors the JP=1+superscriptğ½ğ‘ƒsuperscript1J^{P}=1^{+} assignment and disfavors JP=1âˆ’superscriptğ½ğ‘ƒsuperscript1J^{P}=1^{-} or JP=0âˆ’superscriptğ½ğ‘ƒsuperscript0J^{P}=0^{-}. Regarding the fact that this state could be the Zcâ€‹(3900)subscriptğ‘ğ‘3900Z_{c}(3900), saw in a different decay channel, the only comment from the experimental side is that if the Zc+â€‹(3900)superscriptsubscriptğ‘ğ‘3900Z_{c}^{+}(3900) and Zc+â€‹(3885)superscriptsubscriptğ‘ğ‘3885Z_{c}^{+}(3885) are the same state, then the ratio

Î“â€‹(Zcâ€‹(3885)â†’Dâ€‹DÂ¯âˆ—)Î“â€‹(Zcâ€‹(3900)â†’Ï€â€‹J/Ïˆ)=6.2Â±1.1Â±2.7Î“â†’subscriptğ‘ğ‘3885ğ·superscriptÂ¯ğ·Î“â†’subscriptğ‘ğ‘3900ğœ‹ğ½ğœ“plus-or-minus6.21.12.7{\Gamma(Z_{c}(3885)\to D\bar{D}^{*})\over\Gamma(Z_{c}(3900)\to\pi J/\psi)}=6.2\pm 1.1\pm 2.7 (21)

is determined [17].

Comparing the results in Eqs.Â (20) and (21) we can conclude that, if the ratio in Eq.Â (21) is confirmed, the states Zc+â€‹(3900)superscriptsubscriptğ‘ğ‘3900Z_{c}^{+}(3900) and Zc+â€‹(3885)superscriptsubscriptğ‘ğ‘3885Z_{c}^{+}(3885) are not the same state.

Here again, as in the case of the Zc+â€‹(4025)superscriptsubscriptğ‘ğ‘4025Z_{c}^{+}(4025) discussed above, it is possible that the Zc+â€‹(3885)superscriptsubscriptğ‘ğ‘3885Z_{c}^{+}(3885)) is not a real state but a manifestation of a resonance with a mass below the (Dâ€‹Dâˆ—Â¯)ğ·Â¯superscriptğ·(D\bar{D^{*}}) threshold. This point remains to be clarified.

8 Towards a new spectroscopy

The proliferation of new charmonium states motivates attempts to group them into families. One possible way to organize some of the charmonium and bottomonium new states was suggested in Ref.Â [\refciteNavarra:2011xa] and it is summarized in Fig. 2. In this figure we present the charm and bottom spectra in the mass region of interest. On the left (right) we show the charm (bottom) states with their mass differences in MeV. The comparison between the two left lines with the two lines on the right emphasizes the similarity between the spectra. In the bottom of the second column we have the newly found Zc+â€‹(3900)superscriptsubscriptğ‘ğ‘3900Z_{c}^{+}(3900).

The existence of a charged partner of the Xâ€‹(3872)ğ‘‹3872X(3872) was first proposed in Ref.Â [\refcitemaiani]. A few years later[55] the same group proposed that the Z+â€‹(4430)superscriptğ‘4430Z^{+}(4430), observed by BELLE[7], would be the first radial excitation of the charged partner of the Xâ€‹(3872)ğ‘‹3872X(3872). This suggestion was supported by the fact that the mass difference corresponding to a radial excitation in the charmonium sector is given by MÎ¨â€‹(2â€‹S)âˆ’MÎ¨â€‹(1â€‹S)âˆ¼590similar-tosubscriptğ‘€Î¨2ğ‘†subscriptğ‘€Î¨1ğ‘†590M_{\Psi(2S)}-M_{\Psi(1S)}\sim 590 MeV. This number is close to the mass difference MZ+â€‹(4430)âˆ’MX+â€‹(3872)âˆ¼560similar-tosubscriptğ‘€superscriptğ‘4430subscriptğ‘€superscriptğ‘‹3872560M_{Z^{+}(4430)}-M_{X^{+}(3872)}\sim 560 MeV. A similar connection between Z+â€‹(4430)superscriptğ‘4430Z^{+}(4430) and Zc+â€‹(3900)superscriptsubscriptğ‘ğ‘3900Z_{c}^{+}(3900) was found in the hadro-charmonium approach[83], where the former is essentially a Î¨â€²superscriptÎ¨â€²\Psi^{\prime} embedded in light mesonic matter and the latter a J/Ïˆğ½ğœ“J/\psi also embedded in light mesonic matter. In Ref.Â [\refciteNavarra:2011xa] this reasoning was extended to the bottom sector and it was conjectured that the Zb+â€‹(10610)superscriptsubscriptğ‘ğ‘10610Z_{b}^{+}(10610), observed by the BELLE collaboration in Ref.Â [\refcitebellezb], might be a radial excitation of an yet unmeasured Xb+superscriptsubscriptğ‘‹ğ‘X_{b}^{+}, predicted in Ref.Â [\refcitex3872]. The observation of Zc+â€‹(3990)superscriptsubscriptğ‘ğ‘3990Z_{c}^{+}(3990) gives support to this conjecture and should motivate new experimental searches of this bottom charged state and its neutral partner, the only missing states in the diagram.

9 Conclusion

The most important message from the experimental program carried out at Belle and BESIII is that definitely there is something really new happening in the charmonium spectroscopy. This started in 2003 with the measurement of the Xâ€‹(3872)ğ‘‹3872X(3872), which has a very robust experimental signature and has been neasured by many different groups. The Xâ€‹(3872)ğ‘‹3872X(3872) is electrically neutral and hence its multiquark nature was not clear from the beginning. Five years later, in 2008, the observation of Z+â€‹(4430)superscriptğ‘4430Z^{+}(4430), Z1+â€‹(4050)superscriptsubscriptğ‘14050Z_{1}^{+}(4050) and Z2+â€‹(4250)superscriptsubscriptğ‘24250Z_{2}^{+}(4250) would have been the proof of the existence of multiquark configurations in the charmonium sector. However the non-confirmation of these measurements rendered this claim weak. Another five years later, in 2013, the confirmation of the observation of the Z+â€‹(4430)superscriptğ‘4430Z^{+}(4430) together with the measurements of the Zc+â€‹(3900)subscriptsuperscriptğ‘ğ‘3900Z^{+}_{c}(3900) (which was measured by BESIII and confirmed by other groups) and also of the Zc+â€‹(4025)superscriptsubscriptğ‘ğ‘4025Z_{c}^{+}(4025), Zc+â€‹(4025)superscriptsubscriptğ‘ğ‘4025Z_{c}^{+}(4025) and Zc+â€‹(3885)superscriptsubscriptğ‘ğ‘3885Z_{c}^{+}(3885), reinforced our belief that we are observing multiquark states. What has to be done next? From the experimental side it is necessary to determine unambiguosly the quantum numbers of all these states and eliminate the suspicion that they are mere threshold effects and not real particles. As suggested in Ref.Â [\refcitetokhenno14], this can be done performing an energy scan in the e+â€‹eâˆ’superscriptğ‘’superscriptğ‘’e^{+}e^{-} reactions. Moreover, a more refined analysis will allow us to determine whether all these states are really different. From the theoretical side its necessary to focus on the calculation of the decay widths in all the different approaches, since, as we have discussed, the masses are easily obtained by different methods and they are not sufficient to discriminate between different theoretial models. If our present picture of these states survives all these tests and improvements, we will have found multiquark states. This is in itself very interesting! Whether meson molecules, tetraquarks or hadrocharmonium, these are novel objects which will induce a small revolution in our understanding of hadrons.
